channel.title: Fede’s intern 🥊 / @fede_intern
channel.description: Twitter feed for: @fede_intern. Generated by nitter.freedit.eu

item.title:
The fact that a place has beautiful scenery, has incredibly educated and smart people doesn’t mean it doesn’t have a failed state.
Argentina has incredible scenery too but the state and government are fucked up as hell.
I don’t know enough about California to have an opinion about its state and goverment. I can say I love the people living there and the cities are very nice.
item.dc:creator: @fede_intern
item.description:
The fact that a place has beautiful scenery, has incredibly educated and smart people doesn’t mean it doesn’t have a failed state.

Argentina has incredible scenery too but the state and government are fucked up as hell.

I don’t know enough about California to have an opinion about its state and goverment. I can say I love the people living there and the cities are very nice.

item.title: With @FuzzingLabs we have been working on securing LLMs and it’s starting to pay off. We will be soon able to share interesting findings.
item.dc:creator: @fede_intern
item.description: With @FuzzingLabs we have been working on securing LLMs and it’s starting to pay off. We will be soon able to share interesting findings.

item.title:
We started using @commonwarexyz runtime and actors to implement the p2p and rlpx parts of our L1 execution client ethrex.
We really like the mindset and code simplicity it has. As any codebase it has things to improve but I believe this is how code should be written.
We might reimplement parts of commonware inside ethrex directly. If we do so we will obviously reference it, thank commonware and try to contribute back.
Thanks for the work you guys are doing, hopefully it can help Ethereum too via our work in Ethrex.
item.dc:creator: @fede_intern
item.description:
We started using @commonwarexyz runtime and actors to implement the p2p and rlpx parts of our L1 execution client ethrex.

We really like the mindset and code simplicity it has. As any codebase it has things to improve but I believe this is how code should be written.

We might reimplement parts of commonware inside ethrex directly. If we do so we will obviously reference it, thank commonware and try to contribute back.

Thanks for the work you guys are doing, hopefully it can help Ethereum too via our work in Ethrex.

nitter.freedit.eu/fede_intern/status/1884764387006705898#m

item.title:
I’ve met a lot of people in crypto, and I don’t hand out praise easily. Some of the most efficient and capable people in our industry work at the @ethereumfndn: @TimBeiko, @dankrad, and @drakefjustin. Their work is crucial to the success of the Ethereum ecosystem and crypto.
I think they have the correct long term vision of what needs to be done, what makes Ethereum unique and how to articulate long term needs with short term problems.
One of the reasons we work in Ethereum is because we know we can rely on their research, technical expertise, and ability to execute.
item.dc:creator: @fede_intern
item.description:

I think they have the correct long term vision of what needs to be done, what makes Ethereum unique and how to articulate long term needs with short term problems.

One of the reasons we work in Ethereum is because we know we can rely on their research, technical expertise, and ability to execute.

Ethereum needs to fight in all fronts.
Accept mistakes, improve in what is being done wrong but fight in all fronts.

item.title:
The @solana memecoins market cap (1183 coins, up to the ones that have a market cap below 10k) is 18.4 billions.
Only the memecoins Shiba Inu (SHIB) and Pepe (PEPE) in @ethereum have a market cap of 16.4 billions.
Forum, is this correct?
item.dc:creator: @fede_intern

item.title: Ethereum needs: - based rollup framework with actual code working a la geth when Ethereum started - preconfirmation specifications, work in progress - native specs to handle difference between EVM OPs - better L2 interoperability standards, but based rollups + preconfirmations + native will make things super smooth for the user
item.dc:creator: @fede_intern
item.description:
Ethereum needs:
- based rollup framework with actual code working a la geth when Ethereum started
- preconfirmation specifications, work in progress
- native specs to handle difference between EVM OPs
- better L2 interoperability standards, but based rollups + preconfirmations + native will make things super smooth for the user

item.title:
RT by @fede_intern: OMG! What a mess blockchain address poisoning is!
Didn’t know you could craft 0-value ERC-20 transactions from ANY sender to ANY recipient.
Victim wallets show these fake txs, making it easy to send $$$ to attackers by mistake.
https://arxiv.org/pdf/2501.16681
item.dc:creator: @Istvan_A_Seres
item.description:
OMG! What a mess blockchain address poisoning is!

Didn’t know you could craft 0-value ERC-20 transactions from ANY sender to ANY recipient.

Victim wallets show these fake txs, making it easy to send $$$ to attackers by mistake.

arxiv.org/pdf/2501.16681

item.title: RT by @fede_intern: A lot of ppl announcing "community rounds" but if you look underneath the hood, it's actually mostly just sold to VCs. Pretty disappointing to see ppl try to co-opt the moment and disguise trad fundraises as "community sales". Community rounds don't have 25% of the community allocation reserved for one VC. Anyway, it is what it is, onwards, no respawns, etc etc.
item.dc:creator: @cobie
item.description: A lot of ppl announcing "community rounds" but if you look underneath the hood, it's actually mostly just sold to VCs. Pretty disappointing to see ppl try to co-opt the moment and disguise trad fundraises as "community sales". Community rounds don't have 25% of the community allocation reserved for one VC. Anyway, it is what it is, onwards, no respawns, etc etc.

item.title:
RT by @fede_intern: Credit to L2Beat for making this change. I've argued for a while that OP's fraud proof system doesn't meet the criteria for a Stage 1 rollup because OP can unilaterally disable fraud proofs.
This means that the operator of the rollup can steal funds if >25% of the security council is colluding or offline.
But part of the criteria for a Stage 1 rollup is that it can only steal user funds if >75% of the security council is actively malicious.
This is true for Arbitrum and other Stage 1 rollups. Ensuring that standards are applied consistently is important for the entire ecosystem.
https://forum.l2beat.com/t/stages-update-a-high-level-guiding-principle-for-stage-1/338
item.dc:creator: @_bfarmer
item.description:
Credit to L2Beat for making this change. I've argued for a while that OP's fraud proof system doesn't meet the criteria for a Stage 1 rollup because OP can unilaterally disable fraud proofs.

This means that the operator of the rollup can steal funds if >25% of the security council is colluding or offline.

But part of the criteria for a Stage 1 rollup is that it can only steal user funds if >75% of the security council is actively malicious.

This is true for Arbitrum and other Stage 1 rollups. Ensuring that standards are applied consistently is important for the entire ecosystem.

forum.l2beat.com/t/stages-up…

item.title: RT by @fede_intern: Prysm is already finalizing a devnet distributing blocks using random linear network coding. Signature verification changes so it's not a minor change, but it's also not so bad. Faster blob propagation may be around the corner.
item.dc:creator: @potuz_eth
item.description: Prysm is already finalizing a devnet distributing blocks using random linear network coding. Signature verification changes so it's not a minor change, but it's also not so bad. Faster blob propagation may be around the corner.
